message: Today, FBI Director James Comey admitted that the FBI has been investigating links between the Trump campaign and Russian operatives.  The integrity of our democracy and security of our nation are at stake. We cannot afford any more attempts by President Trump to distract from links between his campaign and Russian officials with fabricated claims of wiretaps. Congress must get to the bottom of this immediately.  The American people deserve answers and they deserve them now.

It is an honor to receive the Blinded Veterans Association's Legislative Champion Award for my bill, the Veterans Medical Access Act, that was signed into law last September. This new law ensures that blinded and catastrophically disabled veterans have access to specialty rehabilitation services that are so vital for their quality of life and independence.

Every day women are pushing boundaries and breaking glass ceilings.  During Women’s History Month, we honor these challengers of the status quo, both past and present, and recognize that the journey towards full equality for women is not yet over.  We must continue the work of breaking down barriers for all our girls.  Know that you have a champion in Congress.

I proudly joined Vice President Joe Biden, Governor Jerry Brown, and House Democrats today to lead the charge against TrumpCare.   It will eliminate healthcare for millions of Americans and drive up costs for everyone else. In the 26th Congressional District alone, TrumpCare will take away coverage from 44,300 people completely, cut 2,400 elderly off from Medicaid nursing home care, and according to the American Hospital Association, result in another 64,500 losing Medicaid.  These are people’s lives! We stand united and ready to fight ahead of tomorrow’s vote!

President Trump once again breaks his promise to take care of our veterans, #Trumpcare would hurt thousands of veterans and their families. #TrumpCare cuts $800 million from Medicaid, which many veterans and military families rely on for care. #Trumpcare would deny tax credits to millions of veterans. We have a solemn duty to care for the millions of veterans across our nation.  We must live up to that promise and vote NO on #Trumpcare.

All our children deserve a meaningful education!  I applaud the U.S. Supreme Court’s ruling yesterday -- by unanimous decision -- that children with disabilities are entitled to more than just a de minimus education.  Rather, these students have a right to a meaningful education so they may reach their full potential. Rightfully, SCOTUS has overturned a prior ruling by Judge Gorsuch that would have undermined rights under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act for students with disabilities.

Today is a victory for the American people. They made their voices heard and said loud and clear: No to TrumpCare!‎ Eliminating healthcare for 24 million Americans is not progress. Eliminating coverage for prenatal care, maternity care, vaccinations, and cancer screening is not progress. Giving $600 billion in tax breaks to the richest Americans, while undermining the solvency of Medicare for everyone else, is not progress. Instead of going backwards, we need to move forward, and make affordable, quality healthcare a reality for everyone.

Had the opportunity to address the American Association of Airport Executives (AAAE) and Airports Council International.  As you may know, Ventura County’s airports contribute over $300 million annually to our local economy and support over 2500 local jobs.  Investments in airport infrastructure are an investment in economic growth and opportunity for businesses across our nation!  Hopeful that Congress will put together a bipartisan infrastructure investment package and an FAA authorization bill that support this critical sector of our economy.

To the thousands of my constituents who wrote, called, and emailed my office to say no to TrumpCare - you made it happen. Your voices, and voices from across the country, made the difference. This was a great win for our democracy. As we move forward, your voice will continue to make the difference.

I am deeply disappointed by President Trump’s Executive Order dismantling the Clean Power Plan, putting public health at risk, and undermining our nation’s efforts to tackle climate change. Instead of creating a cleaner, more competitive economy, this Executive Order takes our country backwards, allows more pollution in our air and water, and stifles economic and job growth. Instead, we should be promoting policies that move us towards a sustainable energy future that creates jobs, halts climate change, and protects clean air and water.

Whether it’s expanding access to child care, or creating opportunities for women veterans to bond and share their experiences, we must do more to support the growing population of women veterans. I am pleased that the House Veterans’ Affairs Subcommittee on Health held a hearing on my bills: the Building Supportive Networks for Women Veterans Act (H.R. 91) and the Veterans’ Access to Child Care Act (H.R. 95). I am thankful for the bipartisan support that my bills received from Subcommittee members. I’ll continue to move these bills forward.

On National Vietnam War Veterans Day, we honor a generation of heroes who served our nation. As the Vietnam Veterans of Ventura County so eloquently state: All gave some. Some gave all. Two years ago, I had the opportunity to visit the Vietnam War exhibit at the Ventura County Museum where, on a wall, the names of 108 Vietnam War veterans from Ventura County were written. Those killed in action, and the artifacts that they left behind, reminded me of the true depth of the sacrifice that our servicemembers make when they take the oath to serve our country. Today, and on every March 29th henceforth, we salute all our Vietnam veterans.  Thank you for your service and sacrifice.

National security must come before partisan politics.  The mounting evidence and increasingly alarming developments in the past few weeks have made it clear that we need nothing short of a thorough, independent investigation into the Trump Administration’s ties to Russia and their involvement with the 2016 Election.

Proud to celebrate César Chávez Day, and to be able to represent Ventura County, where Chavez lived and fought for the rights of immigrants and farmworkers. We must celebrate his legacy by moving forward, not falling backward.

Every American deserves equal pay for equal work.   Pay inequality is more than a women’s issue, it is a family issue. Forty percent of households with children include a mother who is either the sole or primary breadwinner, and two-thirds of families depend on the mother’s income to make ends meet. It is not just a matter of fairness, but the key to ensuring that families can make ends meet, pay the mortgage, and put food on their tables. Wage discrimination also has real consequences, including impacting the ability to buy homes, save for a child’s college education, or retirement.   That is why I am proud to be an original co-sponsor of the Paycheck Fairness Act of 2017 – which would help us enforce existing law that makes wage discrimination illegal. The Paycheck Fairness Act would increase penalties for employers who violate the Fair Labor Standards Act, and would protect employees from retaliation for sharing their wage information with one another or for pursuing a wage discrimination case.   When women succeed, America succeeds!

We need to make sure veterans are protected from fraud and abuse. My bill, the Protect Veterans from Financial Fraud Act, had a hearing today in the Veterans’ Affairs Subcommittee on Disability Assistance and Memorial Affairs. The VA investigates hundreds of cases each year where veterans participating in the Fiduciary Program have their benefits stolen or misused by a fiduciary. My bill would allow veterans to recover their benefits stolen by an appointed fiduciary. I’ll keep working to push forward this bill to help our veterans.

Met with Cecile Richards, President of Planned Parenthood, and other members of Congress to discuss ways we can continue to protect women’s health and access to healthcare.  Planned Parenthood provides healthcare services to 2.5 million people each year and is a critical safety net provider to 1 in 5 women in our nation. It is important we protect access to these services that millions of women and men rely on.  Thank you Cecile for your leadership. #StandwithPP

We’re making progress! Proud House Veterans’ Affairs Subcommittee on Health passed two of my bills supporting veterans today. We must do more to support the growing population of women veterans, and I will continue to push these bills forward to address veterans’ healthcare needs.  Learn more about the bills here:

The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs just released a new tool that allows veterans to check and compare quality metrics, including wait times, services, and patient satisfaction at VA facilities and other community hospitals. Greater transparency and accountability will help strengthen the VA and improve the experience for veterans.

Japan and South Korea are critical international partners in the Eastern Asia region.  This past week I joined other members of Congress, international experts, and South Korean & Japanese elected officials to discuss our vital interests in the region including trade, security, and resource issues. These international partnerships will be key to addressing the pressing issues of our time not only in the Asia region, but globally.  Thank you Prime Minister Shinzo Abe for being such a gracious host to our delegation.

Great meeting with the Student Government at CSU Channel Islands! Your voices are critical to my work in Congress to best support college students in Ventura County.  It is always great to engage our students and hear their diverse views.

Recently had the opportunity to meet with some of the doctors and patients at the Los Robles Hospital Gamma Knife Center. The center does cutting edge work of treating cranial diseases, some that would be impossible to treat otherwise, through precision irradiation.  Supporting innovative businesses in Ventura County is not only vital for our economy, but it also improves the quality of life for so many people.

Did you know Ventura County’s agricultural sector supports nearly 35,000 jobs? California avocados are a key part of our local economy.  I recently met with the California Avocado Commission to discuss the challenges and opportunities for local growers, and will keep working to support the agricultural economy in the region.

On Earth Day, we are reminded that protecting our environment is not only crucial to preserving our world, but it is vital to the health, wealth, and security of our nation. Most importantly, we must stop and reverse the effects of climate change. In standing up for the environment, we must also stand for the respect of science and facts that only seek to inform and serve the public interest. We all hold a responsibility to be good stewards of our world and the future we want to leave behind.
PSA: Ventura County residents please take notice:

We need to meet veterans where they are, and technology offers us new possibilities for providing timely, quality care. That is why I’m proud to co-author the bipartisan Veterans E-Health and Telemedicine Support (VETS) Act, which would improve telehealth services and connect more veterans with the providers they need, no matter where they live.  We must continue to provide our veterans with greater access and options for innovative care.

It's Take Our Daughters and Sons to Work Day! Check out the terrific little ones that visited our district offices. They also took the opportunity to advocate for some key legislative issues including “chocolate milk for everyone!”  I can get behind that. #takeyourchildtoworkday

Pleased to join the VA, VSOs, and my colleagues on the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee at a roundtable today to discuss the needs and concerns of veterans and their caregivers. The VA Caregiver Support Program currently includes over 23,000 caregivers, who provide for the day-to-day needs of wounded veterans, in many cases helping them stay in their home and dramatically improving their quality of life. We need to ensure these caregivers have the tools and support they need.  I am also a co-sponsor of the Military and Veteran Caregiver Services Improvement Act (H.R. 1472) to make veterans of all eras eligible for this critical program.

I am pleased to see my bill protecting veterans & their benefits from fraud & abuse advance to the full House Committee on Veterans' Affairs. There are hundreds of cases each year where veterans have their benefits stolen by a fiduciary.  My bill, the Protect Veterans from Financial Fraud Act, would better allow the VA to make all veterans whole and recover the benefits that they have earned, deserve, and rely on to make ends meet. Read more here:

Today, I joined more than 100 of my colleagues to urge President Trump to take action to protect millions of innocent Syrian refugees who desperately seek a safe haven from the violence and destruction of war.  In the face of suffering and oppression, we must act with courage and compassion instead of fear and isolation.

From the corner café to the innovative new tech start-up, small businesses are a vital part of our local communities and source of prosperity. That is why I will always work to support our small business owners and entrepreneurs here in Ventura County and around the nation and provide the resources they need to succeed.   If you are a local business owner or someone looking to start a new venture I encourage you to check out the links and resources below or call my office for more information: www.ventura.score.org – SCORE’s 6th Annual Small Business Expo takes place NOW. www.venturabusiness.org www.edc-vc.com

As a proud original co-sponsor of the Equality Act, I am pleased to announce that this bill was reintroduced today. Now, more than ever, comprehensive and explicit protections under the law are vital for the LGBT community. The Equality Act would protect all people from discrimination based on their sexual orientation or gender-identity in the workplace, at school, and beyond. No matter who you are, where you come from, or who you love, all people deserve to be treated with dignity and respect, and deserve equal protections under the law.

I had a great meeting yesterday with Secretary Shulkin, Senator Duckworth, and House Veterans’ Affairs Committee Democrats to discuss how we can create a better, veteran-centric, 21st Century VA.  Looking forward to working together to create a more modern VA that will better serve the needs of our veterans.

We have made good progress on ensuring veterans in Ventura County receive efficient, quality care, but there is still much more we can do to make the VA a better, more modern, veteran-centric organization. We must continue to ensure that VA facilities, like the Oxnard CBOC, continue to have the tools, resources and staffing they need to effectively serve our nation’s veterans.   I will continue to keep up the pressure in Congress.

One of the most challenging issues facing the Veterans Benefits Administration is eliminating the backlog of claims appeals.  This morning, the full House Veterans’ Affairs Committee held a hearing to discuss new legislation that we are proposing, the Veterans Appeals Improvement and Modernization Act of 2017.  As a co-sponsor of this legislation, I am pleased that our bill was favorably received by our nation’s Veterans Service Organizations.

Many veterans who return home from war have lower extremity injuries, including blast wounds from IEDs.  The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs is a leader in specialized healthcare to deal with these types of injuries.  Today, the House Veterans’ Affairs Subcommittee on Health held a hearing to discuss these important issues.  As Ranking Member of the Subcommittee, I’m committed to ensuring that we have the necessary providers and resources to care for veterans with these injuries, and raise the standard of care nation-wide.

Joined my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to push for improving VA health care for women veterans at our meeting today with U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs Secretary David Shulkin. With the number of female veterans expected to double over the next twenty years, we need to make sure the VA can adapt and provide the quality health care they have earned and deserve. Democratic Women's Working Group

Republicans, in their obsession to repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA), have forgotten that their job is to make healthcare better for people, not worse.   The bill put forth today would gut patient protections, allow insurance companies to discriminate against those with pre-existing conditions, inflict a crushing age tax on seniors,  and undermine coverage for women, veterans, and families, all while providing a massive tax cut to the wealthy. With less than one day’s notice, this bill was rushed to the floor without a Congressional Budget Office score or analysis of how it will impact the American people.  Despite pleas from millions across our nation, the Republicans have chosen to turn their backs on children, middle-class families, and seniors.  The American people will remember who stood on their side and who didn’t.  I urge them to hold their representatives accountable.

I would like to thank all of the talented young artists who participated in this year’s Congressional Art Competition. The arts promote critical skills in our youth and provide a poignant medium for social and personal expression in our society. I want to congratulate our winner, Hana Rose (third from left), and the other finalists, Sabrina, Margaret, Annie, and Luciano, whose artwork will be displayed in the U.S. Capitol and in my offices.

The timing of President Trump's firing of Director Comey is highly unusual and its implication is deeply disturbing. My Republican colleagues must put country first and work with Democrats to make sure the impartiality of the FBI is restored and the investigation of Russian interference in our political process is carried out without further obstruction or delay. We need a special prosecutor to take over the investigation, and we need one now. The very foundation of our democracy is at stake.

Investing in our transportation infrastructure is also an investment in our local economy and our community. Yesterday, I joined Gold Coast Transit District at the groundbreaking of the future site of their new District Maintenance and Operations Facility in Oxnard. This is the largest transportation project in Ventura County in over a decade. I am thrilled to be a collaborative partner in this project that will bring jobs to our community and improve our public transit system that thousands of residents rely on.

Recently, our community suffered a huge loss with the passing of Henry “Hank” Lacayo, who dedicated his life to bettering our community and country. I will remember Hank for his wise counsel, sincere kindness, and unwavering commitment to service to others. He will truly be missed, but his legacy will continue to live on in the hearts of the many individuals that he touched, including my own. Please read my full statement entered into the Congressional Record honoring Hank and his extraordinary and remarkable life: http://bit.ly/2r9a63p

Happy Nurse Appreciation Week! I would like to take this opportunity to recognize and celebrate the hardworking women and men who are the backbone of our healthcare system. To all the nurses who provide the highest levels of quality care throughout Ventura County, please allow me to express my heartfelt appreciation for everything you do!

On National Police Week, I want to send my deepest thanks to our dedicated and professional law enforcement officers who work hard every day to keep our communities safe. They risk their lives to protect and serve, and we must do all we can to ensure they have the support and resources they need to do their jobs. In Congress, I will continue to advocate for programs and policies that support our law enforcement personnel and their families.
Stunning allegations of obstruction of justice. I urge all of my GOP colleagues to stand-up, and demand the Constitution and rule of law be upheld.

The VA must continually adapt to the complex and changing needs of veterans, which includes addressing the growing number of women veterans. My bill that passed the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee today would expand and continue a highly successful pilot program that has been effective in creating stronger support communities for women veterans.

Proud to join Congresswoman Elizabeth Esty, Congresswoman Annie Kuster, Congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard, in recognizing the critical role women have played in our armed services throughout our history. Today there are more than 200,000 women serving in active duty and the number of women veterans continues to grow. Addressing the needs of our growing population of women veterans is one of my  top priorities and I am proud to support the Deborah Sampson Act that will expand VA services for women veterans including mental healthcare and peer to peer support groups. We must continue to do everything we can to provide the care and support our nation’s male and female veterans have earned and deserve in service to our country! #SheWhoBorneTheBattle.

The appointment of Robert Mueller to investigate Russian interference and Russia's ties to the Trump campaign is a step in the right direction. No one is above the law and it is critical that both the Justice Department, under Mr. Mueller's investigation, and Congress, pursue the facts wherever they may lead, and hold those accountable for any wrongdoing found. We must restore the American people's confidence in their government and the rule of law.

Investments in infrastructure create jobs, fuel our economy, reduce congestion, and improve the quality of life in our communities. It’s #TimetoBuild a 21st Century infrastructure that will meet current and future demands.

Today, my female colleagues and I visited the Women in Military Service for America Memorial, located at Arlington National Cemetery, to lay a wreath honoring our fallen women servicemembers. From Deborah Sampson in the Revolutionary War to our women servicemembers in Afghanistan and the Middle East, women have long fought for our security and freedom. As we pay tribute to them, and all of our fallen heroes, let us also strive to lead our lives by the same spirit of courage and service to our country as they lived theirs.

As we come to the end of Older Americans Month, I want to give a special thank you to all of the extraordinary Senior Corps volunteers that are strengthening our community and helping those in need in Ventura County. In 2016, 530 Senior Corps volunteers provided over 70,000 hours of service in Ventura, Oxnard, Port Hueneme, and Camarillo. These wonderful volunteers do everything from providing after-school tutoring, to helping at local hospitals, to aiding the homeless. Some are even working to build a new senior center in Oxnard. Plus, they are all 55 years old or older! Thank you Senior Corps for making a difference in thousands of lives across our region.

I would like to express my sincere congratulations to these exceptional high school students from across Ventura County, who are the 2017 recipients of the Edison International Scholarship. This achievement will provide these well-deserving students with financial assistance to pursue a higher education in STEM-related fields. I wish all of them continued success in their future endeavors.  From Left to right: Gissele Vazquez, Jesus Contreras Magaña, Mireille Vargas, and Juan Carillo. Not in attendance Michael Morrisey Hanson.

The U.S. Service Academies are elite institutions of higher learning, but more notably they produce and develop our nation’s future leaders. It has been an honor to play a part in the appointment of these nine students to such prestigious schools. Ventura County has a long tradition of sending extraordinary and talented students to the U.S. Service Academies, and this year was no exception. Congratulations to the Class of 2021!

The threat of climate change is real, and we need to get serious about the consequences of our failure to take action.  It will have dire consequences for coastal communities, like Ventura County, and could have disastrous impacts on our food and water supply in California and across the globe. The United States should be a global leader in helping to address these threats head on. I urge President Trump to maintain our nation’s commitment towards clean energy and our leadership in the global efforts to combat climate change by reaffirming our commitment to the Paris Climate Agreement.   California is leading the way in the development of clean, renewable, and sustainable energy, which has helped fuel our economy and create jobs. In 2016, 3 million Americans worked in the clean energy economy and that number continues to grow.

President Trump’s decision to begin withdrawal from the Paris Climate Agreement is a disappointing retreat from American global leadership. If the President and his Administration won’t step up, then state and local governments, private industry, and individual citizens across the country must.  The task of curbing climate change falls on all citizens of the world.  We all must do our part to stop pollution, protect public health, and build a competitive 21st Century, clean energy economy.

Today is #NationalTrailsDay! Don’t miss the opportunity to #FindYourTrail and experience America’s magnificent trails system. Here in Ventura County, we are fortunate to have the beautiful Los Padres National Forest, which has over 200 trails. Also, be sure to look out for the native Matilija poppies that bloom from May to July and can only be found all along the trails of the Los Padres National Forest. For more information, visit https://www.fs.usda.gov/lpnf/. I hope to see you on the trails!

After 48 years, it was an honor to be part of Sgt. David Stull’s pinning ceremony for the Purple Heart he was awarded for injuries he sustained by enemy fire in Vietnam. In 2013, not long after I took office, Mr. Stull contacted my office and we worked with the U.S. Army to secure his Purple Heart, which was so long overdue. My priority has always been and continues to be to ensure that our veterans receive the benefits and the services and the recognition that they have earned and deserve. I would like to thank Sgt. Stull for allowing me the opportunity to join his family and friends and members of the Thousand Oaks Elks Lodge 2477 to recognize him with this award for his distinguished service to our great nation. Read the full story here: http://bit.ly/2rnS6Fu

Last week, I met with Vice Admiral Midgette, Commander of the U.S. Coast Guard Pacific Area, to discuss the Coast Guard’s new permanent home at Point Mugu. The new facility, now known as the Coast Guard Forward Operating Base (FOB) Point Mugu, will include two mission-ready helicopter units, their crews, and support personnel.  This move will allow the Coast Guard to sustain its air search-and-rescue operations and law enforcement and homeland security activities along California’s Central Coast. The move also further solidifies Naval Base Ventura County as a strategic asset to Ventura County and the nation.

I would like to thank the National Association of Hispanic Real Estate Professionals for meeting with me last week. I would also like to acknowledge their great work to encourage homeownership in all communities throughout Ventura County.

We must do all we can to care for and support veterans who are struggling with the invisible wounds of war. Today, the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee heard from a number of experts, most of them veterans themselves, about ways the VA, nonprofits, and the private sector can provide innovative treatment and support for veterans living with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). This includes making alternative and complementary treatments and therapies more accessible to veterans who choose them, as well as providing funding for research into new treatments.

We must work to modernize our air traffic control system and ensure our aviation industry is more safe and efficient.  At today’s hearing, I had a chance to ask Secretary of Transportation Elaine L. Chao about the alternative ways we can get there and ways we can move forward.

The 2007 Wall Street financial meltdown cost millions of Americans their life savings, their homes, and their pensions. With passage of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act, Congress took decisive action to prevent another meltdown. Going forward, many experts – including former Chairman Barney Frank who wrote the original law -- agree that the law needs to be improved so that new regulations are not overly burdensome on our nation’s financial institutions. However, the so-called ‘Financial CHOICE Act’ suggests that the Republicans in Congress have completely forgotten that the financial meltdown ever existed. It’s shocking in its disregard for not only our economic stability and security, but in its refusal to recognize the devastation the meltdown inflicted on America’s working families.

A year ago, 49 lives were lost too soon.  They were lost to hate and senseless violence; simply for celebrating who they were.  Their names are carried in our hearts today and in the hearts of the loved ones and communities they left behind.  Let us echo their stories as a clarion call against hate and fear.  We carry their memory today as a reminder that there is more work to be done, and more progress to be made in the quest for LGBT equality and justice.  We honor their lives with action.  To all those in the LGBT community, know that I see you and I stand with you.

From top to bottom, we must work to make sure the VA has quality staff at every level to carry out its mission of serving our veterans. The vast majority of VA employees work hard to carry out this mission every day. However, when an employee engages in misconduct or puts veterans at risk, we must ensure that the VA is able to hold the individual accountable.   The bipartisan Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act (S.1094) will strengthen the VA system, improve workplace accountability, allow the VA to appropriately discipline or fire bad actors, and better serve our nation’s veterans.

By refusing to answer questions, Attorney General Sessions has exhibited a profound contempt for Congress and the American people, who have a right to know what government officials do behind closed doors. Sessions' deliberate obfuscation leaves us with the obvious conclusion: he is helping President Trump cover-up criminal wrong-doing. If there was no wrong-doing, there would be no need for the rhetorical contortions Sessions engaged in today.
Thoughts and prayers are with Congressman Scalise, Capitol Police, and others hurt in this morning's shooting.

June is #NationalOceansMonth! With over 40 miles of coastline along Ventura County, the Pacific Ocean plays a vital role to our region including our climate, food supply, and way of life. Let's encourage one another to protect and restore #ouroceans and to celebrate their vast beauty.

While I'm very pleased that the Trump Administration will continue President Obama's DACA program that provides DREAMers with the ability to obtain legal work status, I am deeply concerned that President Trump will move forward with removing the parents of DREAMers. The failure of Republicans in Congress to act on comprehensive immigration legislation should not result in our tearing families apart. It does not make sense for public safety, or for our economy, and it does not represent our values as a nation.

Being a mother is one of the great joys of my life, we owe our veterans who have suffered service-connected reproductive injuries the ability to fulfill their dream of raising a family of their own. I am pleased this bill maintains VA coverage for assisted reproductive technology and adoption services, and I will continue to work with my colleagues to ensure that these services are permanently available to our nation’s veterans and their families.

The American people deserve a President who they are confident will serve their best interests and who upholds the U.S. Constitution.  However, more and more, President Trump and his administration have given us reason to be deeply concerned about their motives and the influence of foreign governments through their vast web of personal financial interests.   That is why I join 195 members of Congress who have filed a lawsuit against the President for his violation of the Emoluments Clause of the U.S. Constitution, which prohibits the President from personally accepting gifts or payments from foreign governments. We need to hold the President accountable for the sake of our democracy and our nation.
Ladies of the Hill cheerleading at the 2017 Congressional Women's Softball Game to support the fight against breast cancer!

This Senate Republican healthcare bill would undoubtedly eliminate healthcare for millions of Americans, including many children, women, veterans, and seniors.  It would give retroactive tax cuts to the wealthiest among us, at the expense of middle-class families.  If the House bill was mean, this bill is meaner.  Instead of moving backwards, we need to return to the drawing board and write a bill that would improve our healthcare system. We need to put middle-class families first, and we need to ensure that every American has access to affordable, quality healthcare.

I would like to welcome home the Black Eagles of VAW-113 after their Western Pacific deployment! Their service and sacrifice for those of us here, at home, does not go unnoticed. I would also like to extend my deepest gratitude to the families of those deployed as well. Families serve alongside their loved ones in uniform, and they have done an incredible job managing the day-to-day of that burden. Also, I would like to welcome VAW-115, Liberty Bells, who are now calling NBVC Point Mugu home after spending 44 years in Japan. I know they will continue their mission to protect our country regardless of their location. Welcome home, everyone!

The news today from the Congressional Budget Office that the Senate Republican’s bill will eliminate healthcare completely for 22 million Americans just confirms what we already knew: This isn’t a healthcare bill. It is a tax cut for the wealthy few.  We need to make our healthcare system work better for all Americans, but this bill takes us in the wrong direction. It would undermine healthcare access for veterans, seniors, and women.  It would worsen the opioid addiction epidemic. It would allow insurance companies to impose lifetime caps on coverage and discriminate against those with pre-existing conditions.  I hope my Senate Republican colleagues will go back to the drawing board.  We must ensure that every American has the chance for a healthy future.

We need to do more to help our veterans successfully transition back into the civilian workforce.  I am pleased the House just passed the Veterans Expanded Trucking Opportunities Act, introduced by Rep. Woodall and me, that would streamline the credentialing process for our veterans who wish to enter the trucking industry.  There is a need for new drivers in this industry to keep the flow of goods and our economy going, and our veterans have the skills ready to fill those needs.
Senator McConnell may have delayed the vote on #TrumpCare, but we must keep fighting to #ProtectOurCare  This is what’s at stake:

It was an honor to speak with the National Center for Learning Disabilities this morning. From the local school board, to the State Assembly, to Congress, ensuring that every student has an equal opportunity to succeed is one of my top priorities. Working with my bipartisan Congressional Dyslexia Caucus Co-Chair Lamar Smith, we were able to get the READ Act to the President’s desk last year, which set aside National Science Foundation funds for dyslexia research. But there’s more work to be done, and I urge all advocates to continue driving positive change.

While Pride Month is coming to an end today, I wanted to let members of the LGBTQ+ community know that I stand proudly with you on this day and every day.   The numerous Pride festivals, parades, and marches that happened around the country this past month celebrated not only the LGBTQ community, but also demonstrated the idea that everyone should be able to freely express who they are without fear. These events empower our communities and further reaffirm our values as a country: No matter who you are or who you love, everyone deserves to be treated equally and with dignity and respect.    Pride Month is an important time not only to honor the remarkable progress that has been made towards this goal, but also to come together and stand in solidarity with members of the LGBTQ community who continue to face ongoing discrimination and violence.   There is obviously much more work to do in our shared pursuit for equality and justice. Know that I see you, stand with you, and will continue to fight for the LGBTQ+ community in Congress.

As we celebrate our great nation today, we must remember that no matter what divisions we face, what brings all Americans together are the values of liberty, equality, opportunity, and justice for all.  These ideals are what bind us as a country and what drove dedicated individuals 241 years ago to form a nation under the idea that all men and women are created equal. As a country, we must continue striving to live up to this creed.   Today, let us also celebrate and recognize our servicemembers, veterans, and their families who sacrificed so much so that we may live free and pursue the American Dream.   In that spirit, I wish everyone in Ventura County and around the country a happy and safe Independence Day.

I met with board members from the Ventura County Area Housing Authority to discuss affordable housing in the region, including the HUD-VASH program that helps homeless veterans transition into permanent housing. We have a moral imperative to ensure that everyone has access to quality, affordable housing, and a place to not only live, but also to thrive.

Maryann Hammers of Westlake Village shares her #ProtectOurCare story:  "I was diagnosed with advanced ovarian cancer three and a half years ago. Getting a cancer diagnosis was devastating for me, but I was determined to fight and came out swinging. Luckily, I was able to get treatment and the cancer went into remission. Unfortunately, my cancer quickly recurred less than a year later. So I had more surgery, more chemo, and enjoyed a long 22-month remission. Then the cancer recurred again this spring. Another surgery and back to chemo. That’s where I am now.  "Advanced ovarian cancer may not be curable — but it is treatable. However, those treatments are exorbitantly expensive. That’s why I’m so terrified when I think of what will happen to me, and to the millions of other people with chronic, serious, but treatable conditions — if the Senate bill passes in its current, heartless form.  "The Silver Plan that I purchased through Covered California has been my lifeline throughout multiple surgeries, dozens of chemo rounds, and all the scans, tests, procedures, hospitalizations, complications, follow-ups, and physical therapy sessions that come with a cancer diagnosis.  "The Senate bill takes away many of the protections and health benefits that my life literally depends on.  "If the Affordable Care Act is repealed and the Senate bill passes, I may not be able to get the care I need — to survive.  "And so I implore to our nation’s lawmakers: Please protect our care. Our lives depend on it."

Deborah Madden from Westlake Village shares her #ProtectOurCare story:  "I have a 20-year-old son who has Type I Diabetes. Prior to the Affordable Care Act, it was extremely expensive to maintain health insurance for my son. It was a struggle to afford the premiums, treatments and daily medications vital for his survival. With what is happening in Congress, I am extremely worried about whether we can continue to afford the comprehensive coverage we need for me and our family.    "My son will be graduating from college soon and looking for a job. We have to be careful of him moving out of state. Under the proposed Senate plan, states can use waivers to make comprehensive coverage for pre-existing conditions practically unattainable.    "I am in my 50s, and I rely on private insurance in the individual market as a self-employed American. If companies are allowed to increase my premiums by 500% due to my age, I just simply don't know how I can sustain it even if I dip into my savings.   "Every American deserves access to comprehensive healthcare, and this bill would make it out of reach for our family.   "I urge Congressional leaders to work across party lines to preserve the important protections provided by the ACA."

The Saeta family of Camarillo shares their #ProtectOurCare story:  "Our son, 40-year-old Joshua Saeta, was a generous mentor to many and a loved presence on movie sets.  "Josh taught himself computerized visual effects for the motion picture and television industries. Josh had worked his way up from artist to supervisor where he was very much in demand. Josh never bragged but he was particularly proud of creating the detailed, realistic look of Aslan the lion in the motion picture 'The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' (yes, every time you see Aslan know he was created on computers).  "Josh was taken to an emergency room this past February 2nd where he was quickly diagnosed with pancreatitis and sepsis. Thankfully Obamacare had a mandate that required him to be covered by insurance. Josh could not have anticipated his dire illness.  "On the morning of February 3rd he asked his nurse for medication to treat anxiety. The nurse left his room for at least 14 minutes during which time he suffered cardiac arrest. When he was discovered unconscious, the hospital had all people on deck in an attempt to revive him. His heart was restarted but the damage had been done: Josh suffered anoxic brain injury.  "Josh’s prognosis is still uncertain but at least we have a fighting chance because we have healthcare coverage through the ACA. With it he can continue to receive the care he needs that will give him a chance to regain back a significant portion of his life and once again be a productive member of society.  "Even if I sold my house and everything I built my whole life working in the motion picture industry, I still wouldn’t have been able to afford his care. We are so grateful for the Affordable Care Act that provided funds to California’s Medi-Cal program. Without that Josh would surely be dead.  "Josh is the rock of our family. We love him dearly. So we urge you to please protect our care."

At today’s House Veterans’ Affairs Committee hearing, I had the chance to ask current and former VA officials about the backlog of VA medical facility lease authorizations.    Currently, more than 27 leases are being held up by a bureaucratic dispute over their Congressional Budget Office score. Across the country, this problem is preventing veterans from accessing care and leading to many veterans communities being underserved.   I have been working on a permanent solution to this problem since 2013 when I joined the VA Committee. It’s long past time to approve these leases, permanently fix the scoring problem, and ensure veterans can access more timely, quality healthcare closer to home.

Today, I joined my fellow House Committee on Veterans' Affairs members and experts from VA, HHS, and our nation’s veterans service organizations to discuss solutions to curb the opioid addiction epidemic afflicting our nation, including among veterans who are hit particularly hard by this crisis.   Around 66,000 veterans were treated for opioid addiction at the VA in fiscal year 2016, and the number of veterans living with opioid issues grew by 55 percent between 2010 and 2015. Treatment can also be more complex for veterans, as many are also dealing with co-occurring factors such as depression, PTS, trauma, or homelessness.   We need to explore alternative treatments for chronic pain and take a complementary approach to mental healthcare for our veterans that will address these invisible wounds. I will continue to work with my colleagues to push for more solutions to end the opioid crisis, including within the veteran community.   My bill, the Expanding Care for Veterans Act (H.R. 102), would expand alternative and complementary medicine at the VA, and is one step that I believe would help to address this crisis.

Cindy Liu from Newbury Park shares her #ProtectOurCare story:  “When Sammy was born, she was 7lbs, 10oz, and she immediately melted our hearts. She was born with Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN) and Down syndrome.    “On her third day of life, we nearly lost her when a hole burst in her lung while crying. She was rushed to UCLA’s NICU and placed on ECMO – basically a heart/lung bypass machine that did the breathing for her. It costs $30,000 for a day, and she was in ECMO for 11 days. After ECMO, she fought through four surgeries and was so fragile for two years. A common cold could have killed her.   “The total cost of the hospital stay was $2 million.   “I had to shut down my small business indefinitely to care for her 24/7. Even with my husband’s good employer-based insurance, if the ACA hadn’t become law, our Sammy might have never gotten the care she needed to stay alive because of pre-existing conditions and lifetime caps, and we would probably be broke.  “Medicaid and the waiver program were our lifelines that provided the funding for the in-home nursing and care Sammy needed.  “Today, Sammy is healthy and well. She loves to read, float on ocean waves, ride horses, and can communicate in American Sign Language and English. But we still rely on Medicaid/Medi-Cal for her occupational, speech, and physical therapy; in-home support services; and other school services that allow her to continue living an independent and productive life. So we urge you, please don’t hurt Sammy and her many friends in the Down syndrome community by taking away our care.”

The 2007 Wall Street financial meltdown cost millions of Americans their life savings, their homes, and their pensions. With passage of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act, Congress took decisive action to prevent another meltdown.  We must ensure that the financial security of middle-class families is protected.  Proper regulation of our financial services industry and Wall Street is key to preventing another collapse.  Going forward, the Dodd-Frank law must be improved upon so that new regulations are not overly burdensome on family businesses and small community financial institutions.    However, we must reject wrong-headed solutions, like the so-called ‘Financial CHOICE Act,’ which would completely undo the consumer protections and industry regulations instituted as part of Dodd-Frank.  We cannot go backwards, and we cannot allow rampant, unchecked Wall Street speculators to shake the foundation of our financial and economic systems.  Congress has a responsibility to preserve the financial security and stability of our nation and to protect the American people and their hard-earned retirement savings and homes from another Wall Street melt-down.

Today is my 65th birthday—the official age of eligibility for Medicare. As I celebrate with friends and family, I will be thinking about the more than 100,000 constituents in my district who are also 65 or older and how we must remain steadfast in our promise to all Americans to protect Medicare. I am so proud that Ventura County's 146th Airlift Wing is helping the California National Guard deploy to Texas to aid in Hurricane Harvey rescue efforts. All who are helping to save lives during this disaster are a true testament to the strength of our country. We thank you for your service and dedication!

I am proud of the innovation and ingenuity happening right here in Ventura County. The Department of Energy recently announced funding for a project at Teledyne Scientific Company, based in Thousand Oaks, which is developing a new power converter that could reduce electricity consumption in the manufacturing sector – good for both our environment and our economic competitiveness.

I have filed two amendments to a bill that will be on the floor next week to prohibit the Trump Administration from deporting individuals with DACA status. America made a promise to these DREAMers, and we need to keep it. We urged these young people to come out of the shadows and apply for work permits because they are valuable contributors to our nation. We cannot turn our backs on them now.   These young people came to America as children, and many of them know no other home than the United States. They must be allowed to continue contributing to our economy and our society and get their shot at the American Dream. I will continue fighting for DREAMers because it’s simply the right thing to do.

Women deserve access to the healthcare they need without interference from their employers. I have filed an amendment to a bill that will be on the floor next week that will stop the Trump Administration from moving forward with its plans to let employers interfere with women’s access to affordable birth control. Women should decide for themselves whether they want to take birth control; they shouldn’t need permission from their boss!

I am pleased to announce $300,000 in new federal funding for the City of Ventura to replace outdated water meters, which will help save water and better meet future demand. Reliable access to water is essential for our families and our community. Making better use of technology to monitor and conserve water is a smart way to improve sustainability, make water delivery more efficient, and prepare for future drought conditions.

This past week, I spoke at the Ventura County Behavioral Health Department’s Opioid Solutions Summit. This is a nationwide crisis, and Ventura County is no stranger to its effects. Often, I get heartbreaking emails and phone calls from mothers and fathers, grandmothers and grandfathers, telling me about a family member who they lost to addiction. The misuse of and addiction to opioids is cutting lives short, leaving children orphaned, and tearing families apart. By working together at all levels of government, we can stem the tide of this horrible epidemic.

Are you a legal permanent resident interested in becoming a U.S. citizen? Learn more at a U.S. Citizenship Workshop on Saturday, September 23, in Oxnard. Volunteers will be on hand to assist individuals with the naturalization application, fee waiver assistance, and the filing process. The President’s decision to end the DACA program – effectively ripping the rug out from under nearly 800,000 young people who have been vetted and passed background checks – is heartless and irresponsible. These DREAMers came to America as minors, through no fault of their own. President Trump told them they could ‘rest easy.’ But now he has thrown them into six more months of limbo and uncertainty, turning them into political pawns. House Republicans must allow a vote on legislation to protect these young people because they are valuable assets to our nation. We cannot turn our backs on them.

This morning, I stood with my House and Senate colleagues to call on Republicans to protect DREAMers because deporting them is contrary to our values and would hurt our economy. This afternoon on the House floor, I called for a vote on the Dream Act to help young people like Martha, who grew up in Oxnard and received her bachelor’s degree from CSU Channel Islands and her master’s degree from Pepperdine University. She is now helping the next generation of students on the staff here at Channel Islands and deserves a chance to continue contributing to our community.

I am proud to co-author the Blue Whales and Blue Skies Act, legislation to acknowledge the important role of the maritime shipping industry in protecting our marine mammals. Modeled after a successful Ventura County and Santa Barbara County initiative, the bill would provide national recognition for shipping companies that voluntarily slow ship speeds off our coast. The program not only reduces emissions, improves air quality, and protects blue whales and other marine life, but also demonstrates how local ideas can provide innovative solutions to larger problems. With back-to-school season underway, it is an important time to focus on providing our children with the tools to succeed. That is why I am proud to reintroduce the Biliteracy Education Seal and Teaching (BEST) Act, on International Literacy Day, to help promote bilingual proficiency in our education system. Knowing a second language can give our young people a leg up in today’s globalized, competitive economy. We must do more to ensure they can compete.

From serving our local community every day, to helping fight fires in Los Angeles and Fresno, to traveling to Texas to aid with the Hurricane Harvey rescue efforts, Ventura County firefighters are dedicated to helping those in need, both near and far. Thank you for your service!
My thoughts are with the communities in Florida impacted by Hurricane Irma and all emergency response professionals working to keep people safe.
Today marks 167 years since California was admitted to the Union as the 31st state. I am proud to be a representative of the Golden State!

I am pleased to announce nearly $330,000 in new federal funding for California Lutheran University to continue its efforts to help underserved students at local high schools in communities including Oxnard, Fillmore, and Santa Paula strengthen their math and science skills and pursue a degree and career in those areas. Math and science fields are going to continue to be a critical part of the U.S. economy, and ensuring that all young people have the opportunity to succeed in these fields is paramount. I am thrilled that Cal Lutheran received funding to continue its program helping first-generation college students to prepare for and pursue 21st Century careers.

I am proud to serve as co-chair of the Reinvesting in Our Returning Heroes Task Force, which the House Democratic Caucus has established to develop a jobs and economic agenda to ensure America’s veterans succeed in the job market after their service to our nation. Whether it is highlighting the critical skills that our servicemembers develop during their time in the military or encouraging states to make it easier for veterans to apply their military training toward professional licenses, we must provide wraparound support and services that help veterans get jobs after they have sacrificed for our country. We also must focus on the military families who serve alongside their family member in uniform and can sometimes have their own careers uprooted, but who don’t always get the attention they deserve.

Today marks 23 years since Congress passed the Violence Against Women Act to provide a strong, coordinated response against domestic violence and sexual abuse and assault. Ever since, it has served as the cornerstone of our nation’s efforts to curb these crimes.   I will continue to build on that progress to work to end the terrible domestic and sexual violence that happens all too frequently in our country, whether in our households or on our college campuses, by expanding resources and services and changing the culture surrounding domestic abuse and sexual assault.

Too many Americans are living paycheck to paycheck, and wages aren’t keeping pace with the cost of living. That is why I am proud to co-sponsor the GAIN Act, introduced today by Rep. Ro Khanna and U.S. Senator Sherrod Brown, to expand the Earned Income Tax Credit and put more money back into the pockets of hardworking Americans. The GAIN Act roughly doubles the EITC for working families, including over 3 million veterans and military members, helping them get ahead.

I voted against the FY18 federal spending bill because it does not reflect the values of Ventura County residents. It defunds Planned Parenthood, Title X family planning, and teen pregnancy prevention programs. It cuts investments in infrastructure, local law enforcement, education programs, our national parks, and enforcement of clean air and clean water rules. It also fails to fund opioid addiction treatment programs, which we know are critical to saving lives. This wrong-headed bill does not invest in our future and contains dangerous policy riders that will undermine public health. Rather than wasting time on a bill that has zero chance of becoming law, we should be focused on passing a real, bipartisan budget agreement that reflects our priorities as a nation. I stand ready to work together, and I hope Republicans will join me.

Today on National POW/MIA Recognition Day, we come together as a country to remember our heroes that have not returned home and reaffirm our ironclad commitment to leaving no one behind. When our servicemembers take the oath to serve and defend our nation, we also make a sacred promise to stand by them and their families. Let us continue to stay vigilant in our efforts and unwavering in our promise until all are accounted for.

Throughout Hispanic Heritage Month, I will be highlighting the work and contributions of some wonderful Latino Americans in Ventura County who are working to better our community.  I hope you take the time to learn their stories. For the first post in this series, I would like you to meet Alicia Flores.   As the Executive Director of La Hermandad Hank Lacayo Youth and Family Center, Alicia leads the organization’s efforts to address the inequalities facing our community’s immigrant families, children, and senior citizens. As Congress reconvenes this week, Speaker Ryan and Senator McConnell are planning one last-ditch effort to repeal the ACA with the Graham-Cassidy bill. This bill will have catastrophic effects in California and undermine our healthcare system – hurting our state more than any other by far. We can’t let that happen.  This “healthcare” bill will make Americans pay more for less coverage by gutting key protections for those with pre-existing conditions, threatening essential health benefits like mental health and substance abuse treatment, bringing back lifetime caps, and imposing a crushing age tax. Your voices matter and now they have to be louder than ever.

I am happy the House passed bipartisan legislation extending critical veterans programs. Whether it’s ensuring veterans have access to child care when they have VA appointments, to providing mental health services tailored to the unique needs of women veterans, to putting roofs over the heads of those who are homeless, these VA programs are essential parts of our sacred commitment to care for those who served our nation. Today’s vote is a testament to the success, effectiveness, and popularity of these programs, and I will continue fighting to make them permanent so that every veteran gets the care they have earned and deserve.

I was proud to join my colleagues in the House to pass the American Legion 100th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act today to honor the Legion’s work on behalf of our nation’s veterans. For nearly a century, the American Legion has graciously served and fiercely advocated for our brave men and women who have served in uniform. They work to make sure our nation stays true to its sacred duty to those who served and were instrumental in helping our veteran community achieve major legislative milestones like the GI Bill.

I look forward to working with my colleagues to move this legislation forward.

At today’s House Transportation and Infrastructure Subcommittee hearing, I had the chance to speak with experts about building America’s 21st Century water infrastructure – including Mr. David Pedersen, General Manager of the Las Virgenes Municipal Water District, which serves a portion of my Congressional district. The American Society of Civil Engineers has estimated that there is a $4.6 trillion shortfall in infrastructure investments across the United States. We must invest more at all levels of government, including in our wastewater systems. That is why I am a co-sponsor of the Water Quality Protection and Job Creation Act, which will stimulate growth and rebuild both our nation’s infrastructure and middle-class economic security.

To provide our veterans with the care they need and deserve, the VA must have sufficient staff to serve them. We must do more to retain quality employees and better plan for future demand so our returning heroes receive the care they have earned.

I support HHS Secretary Price's decision to resign. Congress should be focused on policies that create jobs, help middle-class families, and lift seniors and children out of poverty. It breaks faith with our seniors who have spent a lifetime paying into Social Security and Medicare, and guts Medicaid funds, which are the primary source of support for nursing home care for low-income seniors and people with disabilities. It’s time we modernize our outdated infrastructure. I support a new commonsense framework released this week to do just that, which focuses on funding immediate and long-term investments, fixing existing infrastructure deficiencies, and fostering innovation and community development.

While the Iran nuclear deal was not perfect, it was the best mechanism, painstakingly negotiated by the United States, Russia, China, France, the United Kingdom, and Germany, to stop Iran from continuing to develop nuclear weapons. This agreement is critical not only to the safety of our ally, Israel, but also to halting a potential nuclear arms race in the Middle East. It included a rigorous inspection regime, the ability to automatically force sanctions back on Iran in the case of its failure to comply with the agreement, and came with the legitimacy and full force of the support of the President of the United States.  It is universally agreed – including by President Trump’s Defense Secretary, Secretary of State, and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff – that the Iranians have complied with the terms of the agreement thus far. It is clear that the agreement significantly reduced Iran’s ability to acquire nuclear weapons, which inarguably has made the United States and the world safer.  President Trump’s unilateral move to decertify Iran’s compliance with the agreement – with no evidence whatsoever – not only diminishes America’s leadership in the world, destabilizes the Middle East, and makes Israel less safe, but it also makes it significantly more difficult for any country to trust that an agreement with the United States, especially with respect to nuclear nonproliferation, is legitimate.  While Congress must continue to use every tool available to halt Iran’s support of terrorism, we also must uphold this agreement, despite this very reckless action by President Trump.

As Hispanic Heritage Month comes to a close, the final post in my series highlighting the contributions of Latinos in Ventura County features Judge Michele M. Castillo.  Judge Castillo is a pioneer in the California judiciary, and became the first Latina to sit on the Ventura County Superior Court in June 2016. For over a decade, she has tirelessly served our community and its people through the justice system. She served as a court commissioner prior to becoming appointed by Governor Brown as a Superior Court Judge, where she oversaw hearings involving domestic violence, civil harassment, workplace violence, transitional housing, custody, and child and spousal support.  Prior to serving on the bench, she was a fierce advocate on behalf of some of the most vulnerable populations, including our veterans and people who are homeless, in her former capacity as a Ventura County Deputy Public Defender. Throughout her career, Judge Castillo has worked on thousands of cases. She has fought to ensure that the values of fairness and justice are upheld, and our legal system and the community she serves are better because of it.  Judge Castillo is a graduate of the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), the Thomas Jefferson School of Law, and the University of Oxford, where she earned a certificate in international human rights law and the international rights of women.

Today, the House Committee on Veterans’ Affairs held a hearing on legislation to improve veterans’ access to quality care, including a bill to update the Veterans Choice Program and a bipartisan bill I co-authored with Congressman Glenn “GT” Thompson to expand access to telemedicine at the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs. Our top priority must be to provide veterans with the best care possible, as timely as possible. That means a modern and innovative VA, care in the community when it makes the most sense for veterans, and leveraging the rapid advancement of technology in all aspects of healthcare delivery. I look forward to continuing to work together with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to ensure the VA healthcare system best serves our nation’s veterans.

We held a moment of silence today in the House to honor the lives lost to the California fires and to reaffirm our commitment to help those who have been impacted. I will keep working to ensure our state has the resources it needs to support our first responders, as well as those who are working to rebuild their lives.

I stood with my colleagues yesterday during #DomesticViolenceAwarenessMonth because we must #StoptheAbuse affecting 1 in 3 women and 1 in 4 men. I spoke about one population that is especially vulnerable to domestic violence – those who are undocumented – and the bill I am introducing to enable more survivors to come forward without fear of deportation to help law enforcement.

Domestic Violence Awareness Month is a reminder that there is more we must do to help law enforcement get violent criminals off the streets and aid survivors of domestic abuse and other serious crimes in finding safe haven. There are too many heartbreaking stories of individuals who want to report their abuser to the police or have witnessed a crime, but are afraid that coming forward could result in their own deportation. Today, I introduced the “Protect Victims of Crime Act” to expand the U visa program for survivors of serious crimes, like domestic abuse or sexual assault. This bill will strengthen law enforcement’s ability to go after criminals and protect survivors from future abuse. Read more here: https://juliabrownley.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/as-part-of-domestic-violence-awareness-month-brownley-introduces-protect

While it’s clear that women on the battlefield undergo the same kinds of trauma that men do, we know that women’s experiences in the military and when they come home can be very different. It was an honor to speak at the Capitol Hill screening of a new documentary, “Served Like a Girl,” shedding light on the experiences of women who have served our country in uniform. Thank you to Senator Tammy Duckworth for hosting this event!

Budgets are statements about our values. The Republicans' Fiscal Year 2018 Budget Resolution will harm seniors, veterans, children, and working families – all to pave the way for tax cuts that give 80% of the benefits to the top 1%. Meanwhile, the House and Senate GOP have thrown out even the pretense of caring about fiscal responsibility, voting to add another $1.5 trillion to the national debt, the burden of which will fall heavily on our children.  Instead of exploding the national debt to benefit the top 1%, we should be taking real actions to boost our economy, like investing in education, job training, and rebuilding our crumbling national infrastructure, and taking bipartisan steps to lower our national debt.  The values and priorities of the GOP are wrong for the economy, wrong for the hardworking men and women of our country, and wrong for our children.

Private sector research has demonstrated the effectiveness of medical marijuana as an option to help patients address numerous conditions, and it is long past time for the federal government to update our laws in this area. Last year, a bipartisan majority of the House voted to require the VA to lift its prohibition on doctors prescribing medical marijuana in states where it is legal. I was disappointed that the provision was stripped from the final bill, and I will continue to work to get these changes enacted into law. This week, I also joined my Democratic colleagues on the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee to urge the VA to conduct research into the potential benefits of medical marijuana for veterans coping with chronic pain and post-traumatic stress disorder. I am hopeful this research will help us move the ball forward to update federal laws in this area.

I am pleased to announce that California Lutheran University has been awarded two federal grants totaling more than $350,000 to support underrepresented students at both the K-12 and post-baccalaureate levels. From giving local students the chance to harness their abilities and get on the path for higher education success, to encouraging a diversity of perspectives and backgrounds at the doctoral level, this funding will help make sure every student has the opportunity to reach their full potential and attain success in higher learning.

My heart breaks for the New York City victims and their families, and my gratitude goes out to the first responders. New Yorkers are among the most resilient people in the world, and their bravery in the face of tragedy is inspiring. I know they will be there for each other to heal, and the country will be there with them.

The House Veterans’ Affairs Committee passed the VETS Act, bipartisan legislation I co-authored with Congressman Glenn “GT” Thompson (R-PA) that will allow the VA to expand telehealth services and provide more care to veterans right in their own homes. We must continue to leverage new technologies to improve VA care. I look forward to working with my colleagues in the House to pass this bill.

I was proud to join The American Legion National Headquarters and House Veterans’ Affairs Committee Ranking Member Tim Walz yesterday to talk about the need for federal research into the effectiveness of medical marijuana for helping veterans with chronic pain and PTSD. Medical marijuana has the potential to be an effective, alternative treatment to opioids. I will continue to work in Congress to update federal laws in this area and push for more research that could result in more effective treatments.

Republicans tout that they want to help middle-class families, but the tax cut bill they unveiled yesterday clearly shows that what they really care about is putting billionaires first.   Their giveaway to the rich eliminates deductions that are critical for middle-class families in California, including the state and local income tax deduction, the medical expense deduction, the student loan interest deduction, and the dependent care credit. They also limit the property tax deduction and the mortgage interest deduction for future homebuyers.   The message this bill sends to middle-class Americans is loud and clear: If you want to go to school to better your education, you have a child in daycare, you are buying a home for your family for the first time, or you have major medical expenses from cancer or other life-threatening conditions, Republicans don’t care.  This windfall for the 1% also forces our country deeper into debt – putting more pressure on Medicare and Social Security and sticking our grandchildren with the bill. Despite Republicans’ claims, most reasonable economists say that tax cuts funded by adding to the deficit are not the path to economic growth.  We know a scam when we see one. Americans deserve a better deal – one that will help working class families instead of special interests. Speaker Ryan needs to scrap this plan so that we can work on a bipartisan bill that actually reforms the tax code and helps middle-class families.

House Republicans are willing to add $1.5 trillion to the national debt in order to fund tax cuts that predominantly benefit the wealthiest 1%. Yet, when it comes to providing healthcare to low-income children and keeping community health centers and hospitals open, Paul Ryan demands we pay for it by taking money from seniors. These priorities are completely out of whack. This bill presents false choices, pitting the needs of poor children against other public health programs. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities has also warned that this bill could result in up to 688,000 families losing health insurance altogether.  I firmly support reauthorization of the Children’s Health Insurance Program, community health centers program, assistance for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands, and protecting our hospitals from devastating funding cuts. However, in the process, we do not have to gut other essential public health programs, throw families off of health insurance, or divert Medicare funds.  Time is of the essence. I look forward to negotiating a better, bipartisan deal with our Senate colleagues to fund these important programs.

It is heartbreaking that an average of 20 veterans commit suicide each day. One veteran life lost to suicide is one too many. By shining a light on this topic, I hope we can reduce the stigma around mental health issues, and continue to work to address this devastating epidemic.

It is an honor to represent Naval Base Ventura County and its more than 19,000 active duty and civilian personnel, all of whom have bravely dedicated themselves to safeguarding our nation’s security. The legislation passed today will help ensure the continued operation of our base and other military installations around the globe, as well as provide a well-earned pay raise for active duty military personnel. The first Triton was delivered to Point Mugu last week, the west coast home for this next-generation unmanned aircraft.  I am pleased to see this bill pass today and will continue to fight to protect Naval Base Ventura County and ensure our entire Armed Forces have the resources they need.

We need to reform the federal tax code to reduce the tax burden on working families and small businesses, incentivize innovation, and spur real job growth. Unfortunately, the tax bill that House Republicans passed today doesn’t do that.  Instead, this scam gives a massive tax cut to the very wealthy and large corporations that outsource jobs at the expense of seniors, veterans, parents, homeowners, students, and middle-class families. The truth is that millions of Americans will see tax increases if this bill becomes law. It’s especially bad here in California, where 28 percent of taxpayers – mostly middle-class families – will see their taxes go up.  This bill also adds another $1.5 trillion, plus the added interest payments, to the national debt – endangering Medicare and Social Security for our seniors and sticking our children and grandchildren with the bill.  Unfortunately, the Senate version of the bill is even worse. It is going to drive up healthcare premiums for working families and would be even more costly for California’s middle-class families because it also ends the property tax deduction.  As this process continues to move forward, I will keep fighting for a better deal for Californians and working families across the country because we simply cannot allow this tax bill to become law.

Everyone has the right to work in a safe environment free from harassment, abuse, and intimidation. Mandating anti-harassment training for all Members of the U.S. House of Representatives, as well as all staff and interns, is an important first step to ensure a climate of respect in our workplace. However, Congress must make changes to create additional accountability and transparency in how it handles any and all complaints about harassment or discrimination and to guarantee justice for all victims. Congress should be a national leader and role model for protections for individuals at workplaces across the country. I will continue to work with my colleagues to ensure that is the case.

I had the opportunity to meet with the Veterans of Foreign Wars VFW Women’s Committee today. I look forward to continuing to work with them and all of our Veterans Service Organizations to ensure that the VA adequately serves the needs of the fast-growing population of female veterans.

Many brave individuals around the country have come forward to share their stories of harassment through the #MeToo campaign and have shined a bright light on the need to address this inappropriate behavior. Congress must ensure justice for victims of sexual harassment and be the gold standard for protections in the workplace. I’m proud to cosponsor the ME TOO Congress Act, legislation to better address sexual harassment and discrimination in Congress. This bill overhauls the dispute resolution process, implements a speedy complaint process, protects employees from any form of retaliation, and holds Members of Congress — not taxpayers — accountable for paying harassment settlements. You can count on me to continue working with my colleagues to advance this important legislation.

Yesterday, my colleagues on the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee and I approved the “Disaster Recovery Reform Act,” which will improve federal disaster response programs, including by emphasizing the importance of pre-disaster planning and mitigation. These changes will help encourage state and local governments to prepare for, and mitigate against, the impacts of future disasters. These changes will save lives and reduce the costs of rebuilding after future disasters.

Our service branches instill leadership, a strong work ethic, and grace under pressure – all skills required to be successful as an entrepreneur. Today, President Trump drastically reduced the boundaries of the Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monuments, which opens them up for mining, drilling, and other harmful commercial activities. I firmly believe that we need to overhaul the U.S. tax code. Tax reform that makes the system fairer for middle-class families, helps small businesses, and encourages entrepreneurship and innovation is long overdue. Unfortunately, if you look at the House and Senate bills, they don’t achieve these goals.  While there are differences between the two bills that Republicans are trying to work out, nonpartisan economists have already shown that when you add the different provisions up, the Ryan-McConnell plan raises taxes on millions of middle-class families. I want middle-class families and small businesses to get a tax cut, so I will keep fighting for real tax reform.

As 2017 comes to a close, it is a time for reflection on both the joys we have experienced in the past year, as well as the challenges. How we face the good, and the bad, is a reflection of who we are as a people. Nothing puts this into starker clarity for me than the horrific fire we faced this past month in our community.   The Thomas Fire is the largest wildfire officially recorded in California history. Thousands of people were forced to evacuate, homes and livelihoods were destroyed, and most tragic of all – two lives were lost to this terrifying blaze. I cannot even begin to comprehend the firestorm of terror faced by so many of our friends and neighbors, nor can I quantify the magnitude of loss that they are facing as they return to where homes and businesses once stood. The impact on the lives of so many is palpable as I travel across Ventura County.   But through this disaster, we must take note of the heroism, generosity, and caring that also came from our community. First and foremost, it was brought out by the dedication of our brave first responders. Federal, state, and local officials exhibited exceptional teamwork, moving quickly into action to save lives. They went with few breaks and even less sleep to help keep our community safe. Thank you to all of the public safety officials, including many who came from far away counties and states to help support this effort. We also must thank the families of these officers – so many of whom had their own homes in harm’s way. And most importantly, we must express our deepest gratitude and sorrow to the family of firefighter Cory Iverson. His sacrifice will not be forgotten, and his bravery is an inspiration to us all.   The strength and character of our community was also brought out by the countless neighbors helping neighbors. From texts and calls warning of the fire, to support at the evacuation centers, to the donations that poured in from across the region, the true heart of Ventura County – a giving, caring, and generous heart – was on display during the Thomas Fire.   In addition to a time for reflection, the new year is also a time for renewal. January 1 happens to be the day on which the County of Ventura was formed back in 1873. I think it is especially appropriate this year to celebrate the birthday of our county, and its beautiful landscape and remarkable people, as a day of rebirth as we start a new year and the process of rebuilding and recovering.   So as we rebuild from this tragedy, I wish everyone a happy new year and a 2018 that is filled with joy, prosperity, and light.
